tweet: Growing up, we counted every penny, and tariffs only make life harder for low-income families.
Poorer households spend more on traded goods as a share of their income, bearing a disproportionate burden.
Tariffs aren't just taxes on trade—they're taxes on working families. #LowerPrices
Steel tariffs promised jobs, but at what cost?
For every job created, U.S. consumers paid $900,000 in higher prices.
My neighbor lost his job in manufacturing due to rising steel costs—proof that tariffs hurt more than they help. #JobsOverTariffs
My cousin works in agriculture, and retaliatory tariffs have slashed demand for U.S. crops abroad.
The 2018–2019 tariffs not only failed to increase employment but also reduced jobs in sectors like farming.
Tariffs don’t just raise prices; they shrink opportunities. #FairTradeForAll
Buying a washing machine last year was a nightmare—prices had soared due to tariffs.
Research shows consumers paid $817,000 in extra costs for every new job in that industry.
Families like mine are paying the price for policies that don’t deliver on their promises. #TariffsHurtUs
